items.content_html:
Description

This PR mainly switch to workflow_call instead of workflow_run event to prevent calling "PR review companion" when not necessary.

To achieve this, and take this opportunity to improve the code, the following changes were made:

  1. Use pull_request_target event instead of pull_request, with the former event, the GITHUB_TOKEN has write permissions and the jobs could access GitHub secrets (we are using secrets to store the AK, SK).
  2. Set the permissions of the "tests" job to read-all to avoid accidental writes to the repo.
  3. Run the "PR review companion" as a spread job (named "review") in "PR test", so we could use if condition to skip unnecessary runs,
    Set the permissions of "review" job to write-all, so the deployer could create comment in PRs.
  4. Use actions/download-artifact instead of js scripts, as the shared "PR review companion" workflow is a spread job in "PR test" now, we could use this action to download and unzip artifacts (simplifies the steps).

Security statement

Because the GITHUB_TOKEN generated in workflows that triggered by pull_request_target event has write permissions, we need to avoid malicious damage to the repo by the PR author.

  1. Set permissions to different jobs: as the first job would run js scripts which could be modified by PR authors, set the permission of this job to read-all (as we still need the GITHUB_TOKEN to access some resouces).
  2. The pull_request_target event would trigger the workflow runs with the main version of workflows (including the shared workflows - "PR review companion"). This has been tested by Onkar - yin1999#6, and has been documented by GitHub Docs:

    Although the workflow runs in the context of the base of the pull request, you should make sure that you do not check out, build, or run untrusted code from the pull request with this event.

  3. The workflow triggered by pull_request_target event could also access GitHub secrets. But GitHub Actions can only read a secret if you explicitly include the secret in a workflow.

Related issues and pull requests

implementation of: #28579 (comment)
items.title: refactor(ci/pr-review): use `workflow_call` instead of `workflow_run` event

items.content_html:
Description

Correcting the implicit ARIA role in the technical summary table for the summary element.

Motivation

To ensure the MDN docs follow the relevant HTML specs.

Additional details

User scottaohara is an editor for the HTML AAM spec and the ARIA in HTML spec. He states in the linked issue that the table should:

  1. Be updated to reference what the ARIA in HTML spec says
  2. Include the ARIA in HTML spec in the Specifications section

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes #28446
items.title: Correcting technical summary table for <summary>

items.content_html:
The rAF callback timestamp is not identical to the value returned by performance.now(). I was wrong a few months back. I'm don't remember exactly what I based that on. My only excuse is that I was recently back to programming after a few year hiatus. Sorry.

Here I have corrected this mistake and added some detail. For an example of this in action: https://codepen.io/sidewayss/pen/XWorEoz

Open the console pane and see the results. On Chrome I have seen the difference be >17ms or <0.3ms. On Firefox it's always <3ms. I can't get it to run on my older iOS device. performance.now() always returns a value that is higher than (ahead of in time) the rAF callback timestamp, which makes sense once you understand how it works. This stackoverflow puts this a proper context on this and has detail that should be integrated into this page too: https://stackoverflow.com/a/38360320/4941356

I'll take a crack at rewriting my changes to include some of that context and detail.

The rAF callback timestamp is coarsened to 2 decimals on Firefox and 3 on Chrome. The page for performance.now() doesn't mention the way that Firefox has coarsened it to 2ms, which is a lot higher than the 100microseconds everyone else seems to be using, maybe that detail should be added there? If anyone has more specifics on the coarsening of the rAF callback timestamp, they should probably be added here.

This answer on stackoverflow goes into some detail about the timestamps too: https://stackoverflow.com/a/57549862/4941356
items.title: rAF callback arg vs performance.now(), fixes my previous mistake

items.content_html:
Description

Chrome 116 supports various Fed CM API extensions (see ChromeStatus entry). This PR adds documentation for those extensions:

  • context
  • loginHint
  • getUserInfo()

See my research document for more details of what the extensions are.

Motivation

Description

The Document Picture-In-Picture API is supported in release Chrome version 116 (see ChromeStatus entry). This PR adds docs for this API.

See my research document for more details of exactly what has been added.

See also mdn/dom-examples#224 for a complete demo.

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
